S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: Outline of Related Studies
S2.T1.table:
Study Year Environment Dataset Attacks Method Pros (+) & Cons (-)
[30] 2018 FANETs UAV dataset GPS spoofing, Jamming, Blackhole, Grayhole Hybrid + take advantage of rule-based and anomaly-based detection
(from 50 to 250 nodes, 2D deterministic mobility model) - as the number of nodes increases, DT decreases and FPR increases.
[11] 2020 FANETs CICIDS2017 [28] Brute force, DoS, BotNet, Port Scanning ML + multi-agent-based IDS is proposed
SQL Injection, XSS, Heartbleed - the dataset is not suitable for FANETs
- semi-supervised machine learning methods are not evaluated
[17] 2021 Cellular Connected UAV Networks CSE-CIC-IDS2018 [41] Brute force, DoS, DDoS ML + a study on cellular-based study
BotNet, Web Attack, Infiltration - the dataset is not suitable for FANETs and 5G networks
[13] 2022 UAVs DJI Phantom 4 [14] DoS attacks ML + different types of ML-based algorithms are evaluated
- focused on sensor-based attacks rather than FANETs-specific attacks
[15] 2022 UAVs AWID2 [16] (for training and testing in simulation) DoS attacks ML + various ML-based algorithms are assessed with real UAVs
individual UAV data transmission (for real testing) + providing hyperparameter optimization using Bayesian algorithm
(speed, pitch and temperature, etc.) - dataset is not suitable for FANETs
[22] 2022 FANETs UAV-IDS-2020 [23] attacks for unauthorized access in WLAN ML + data collected from real UAVs were used.
- dataset is not suitable for FANETs
[10] 2023 UAVs UAV dataset GPS Spoofing ML + various ML-based algorithms are tuned and evaluated
(a real UAV was used)
[18] 2023 FANETs a FANET dataset Sybil ML + a new dataset is created
(100 nodes, 3D INET’s MassMobility) - it is evaluated on a small area with nodes having low speeds (10-20 m/s)
- high false positive rate
[20] 2023 FANETs a FANET dataset Time Delay ML + a new dataset is created by using 4 different routing protocols
(13, 24 nodes and 2D MapRouteMovement) - 2D mobility is considered
- use of pre-planned route for … applications
[24] 2021 FANETs KDDCup’99 [25] DoS, DDoS, Probe, R2L, U2R DL + both local and central IDSs participate in detection
NSL-KDD [26] Fuzzer, Analysis, Backdoors, Exploits - the datasets are not suitable for FANETs
UNSW-NB15 [42] Worms, Shell Code, Reconnaissance
WSN-DS [43] Password, XSS, Injection, Scanning
CICIDS2017 [28]
TON_IoT [44]
[29] 2019 FANETs a FANET dataset collected from nodes Spoofing, Jamming DL + it is claimed to be lightweight
(20 nodes, Random Way Point Mobility Model ) - the resource consumption is not given in the results
- the dataset is collected using 2D mobility model
[27] 2021 FANETs CICIDS2017 [28] Brute force, DoS, DDoS DL + offline-learning is proposed, where UAVs can update models during charging
BotNet, Web Attack, Infiltration - the dataset is not suitable for FANETs
[40] 2020 IoT NSL-KDD [26] DoS, U2R, R2L, Probing attacks for training FL + data distribution is explored for different types of attacks
17 different attack types for testing - the dataset is not suitable for IoT
[39] 2021 IoT Bot-IoT [45] DoS, DDoS, Theft, Reconnaissance FL + different learning algorithms are evaluated
MQTTset [46] Specific Attacks against MQTT + the dataset is collected from heterogeneous devices
TON_IoT [44] Password, Backdoor, XSS, Injection, Scanning - data distribution is mimicked for FL
[31] 2019 FANETs CRAWDAD [35] for VANETs Jamming FL + a client group prioritization technique is proposed
a FANET dataset (6 nodes, 3D GM Mobility Model) - the effect of mobility on client group prioritization is not discussed
- it is evaluated on very small networks (6 & 3 clients)
[33] 2023 UAV swarm WSN-DS [43] Blackhole, Grayhole, Flooding ML + various ML-based algorithms are evaluated
UAV attack dataset [36] Ping DoS - a significant percentage of the normal class is classified as grayhole
(6 real UAVs) GPS Spoofing, Jamming FL - blackhole attacks ands normal traffic falsely detected as grayhole
Our 2023 FANETs a FANET dataset Sinkhole, Blackhole, Flooding FL + a new dataset is created
Study (50 nodes, 3D GM Mobility Model, + extensive simulations are carried out
attacker ratios: 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, + rigorous comparison with centralized and local intrusion detection
high speed: 720km/h) - communication cost during training
references: All related studies are summarized in Table I. As shown in the table, the majority of these studies train and evaluate their models on datasets not suitable for FANETs. Even in cases where new attack dataset for FANETs are created, their parameters are not very realistic due to simulating networks with a small number of nodes [31], 2D mobility models [20][29], or nodes with low speeds suitable for MANETs and VANETs but not FANETs [18][20]. Hence, such parameters may not accurately reflect the reality of FANETs. In contrast, our study simulates a total of 160 networks for three attacks (sinkhole, blackhole and flooding) with varying attacker ratios (from 5% to 25%) using 3D Gauss Markov Mobility (3D GM). To the best of our knowledge, this work represents the first proposal of a federated learning approach for these attacks. While a few federated learning-based studies have been proposed for jamming and spoofing attacks, their suitability has not been thoroughly evaluated in realistic network scenarios. Our study addresses this gap by exploring the use and suitability of federated learning for intrusion detection in FANETs, offering an extensive comparison with centralized and local IDS in terms of accuracy, communication cost, and privacy.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Network Simulation Parameters
S4.T2.table:
Parameters Values
Routing protocol AODV
MAC protocol IEEE 802.11b
Simulation time 1800 seconds
Simulation area 12000 m x 12000 m x 300 m
Number of nodes 50
Node speed 720 km/h
Transmission range 250 m
Traffic type UDP with 10 connections
Packet size 512 bytes
Packet rate 1/s
Bandwidth 11 Mbps
Attacker ratio no attack, 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%
Mobility model 3D GM
Bounds for GM Mobility X: [0; 12000], Y: [0; 12000], Z: [0; 300]
α𝛼\alpha for GM Mobility [0.25-0.7]
references: Attacker nodes were randomly selected from non-source or non-destination nodes. For each attacker ratio, ranging from 5% to 25%, attacker nodes were chosen randomly. These same attacker nodes were used consistently in each attack type. The network simulation parameters are listed in Table II. These parameters were carefully chosen to align with real-life scenarios, considering factors such as 3D natural flight patterns, realistic speeds, area selection, and an adaptable routing protocol for dynamic FANET movements. More details on parameter selection can be found in our previous study [51].

S4.T3.caption: TABLE III: Dataset Information
S4.T3.table:
Attributes Values
Number of network simulations 160
Number of samples 5,492,700
Number of features 31
Labels Normal, Attack
Attack Type Sinkhole, Blackhole, Flooding
Number of nodes 51
Data collection period every 5s
references: In our data collection process, we gathered features introduced in [52] from each node. The features extracted encompass a range of characteristics, some related to mobility, while others related to AODV control messages and data packets, as detailed in [52]. For instance, there are features that provide insights into the frequency of forwarding, sending and reception of routing protocol control packets (RREQ, RREP, and RERR). Additionally, there are features that give information about changes in the routing table. These features are collected periodically from each node, with a feature collection period set to 5 seconds. The dataset information is summarized in Table III. Please note that while the frequency of data collection positively affects the performance of the system, it also increases resource consumption. Further exploration of trade-offs in the selection of this parameter can be conducted in future studies.

S4.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Deep Learning Parameters
S4.T4.table:
Algorithms Parameter Value
DNN Number of neurons 8 - 16
Number of hidden layers 2
CNN Number of nodes 8 - 16
Number of hidden layers 2
Convolutional layers 1 Conv1D
Pooling layers 1 MaxPool1D
Dropout 0.1
Kernel size 3
Filters 22
Used in both Optimizer SGD
Learning rate 0.01
Loss function binary_crossentropy
Batch size 32
Activation function ReLu
Classification function sigmoid
Number of local epoch 1
Number of global epoch 100
references: These approaches have a number of parameters that need to be tuned for optimal performance. To find the best parameters for the models, the Grid Search method is employed. This method exhaustively searches a predefined set of hyperparameters and selects the combination that produces the best performance. The best parameters selected for optimum performance are shown in Table IV. The performance of models is evaluated on the test set using the following metrics: accuracy, detection rate (DR) and false positive rate (FPR). The final results are obtained by averaging the results of the method applied to different topologies for each IDS.

S5.T5.table:
C-IDS L-IDS FL-IDS
Attacker Ratio (%) DNN CNN DNN CNN DNN CNN
5 69.03% 82.85% 62.39% 72.99% 64.00% 70.44%
10 80.21% 93.33% 67.54% 81.19% 82.00% 89.19%
15 81.53% 95.21% 70.54% 85.40% 89.41% 94.07%

references: In this subsection, the performance of DNN and CNN algorithms is compared for all simulated attack types. The results are shown in Tables
V
VI
VII

for sinkhole, blackhole, and flooding attacks, respectively. Across all IDSs, CNN outperforms DNN. The same trend is observed for the proposed FL-based approach. In FL-IDS, while CNN is better than DNN across all attacker ratios, the gap between the two algorithms widens as the attacker ratio increases. Since CNN consistently outperforms DNN, we will present only the CNN results in the subsequent sections. For a comprehensive view of all results for each algorithm, please refer to our website
https://wise.cs.hacettepe.edu.tr/projects/fanetSec/

S5.T8.caption: TABLE VIII: Performance Improvement with BTSC in Detecting Sinkhole Attack
S5.T8.table:
Attacker Ratio (%) FL-IDS (without BTSC) FL-IDS (BTSC)
5 70.44% 82.96%
10 89.18% 95.26%
15 94.07% 97.63%
20 97.41% 99.48%
25 97.70% 99.62%
references: We also employed an approach called Bias towards specific clients (BTSC) in order to improve the performance of FL-IDS at low attacker ratios. The approach involves giving more weights to the better detecting clients, as some clients may be better at detecting attacks than others due to the dynamic nature of FANETs. In the federated aggregation, 5% of the clients are taken, allowing us to focus on the best detectors. The results obtained with BTSC are shown and compared with the FL-IDS trained with all clients in Table VIII. As shown in the results, when the federated model is trained with the best clients, FL-IDS outperform C-IDS even at the lowest attacker ratio.

S5.T9.caption: TABLE IX: Performance Improvement with BTSC in Detecting Blackhole Attack
S5.T9.table:
Attacker Ratio (%) FL-IDS (without BTSC) FL-IDS (BTSC)
5 65.04% 79.80%
10 90.00% 95.70%
15 95.10% 98.53%
20 99.04% 99.56%
25 99.26% 99.85%
references: The performance of FL-IDS is enhanced by employing the BTSC method as shown in Table IX. When FL-IDS is trained with the weight of the best clients, it achieves high accuracy results, surpassing C-IDS. On the other hand, while its performance reaches 80% accuracy at the lowest ratio, C-IDS still achieves the best performance.

S5.T10.caption: TABLE X: Performance Improvement with BTSC in Detecting Flooding Attack
S5.T10.table:
Attacker Ratio (%) FL-IDS (without BTSC) FL-IDS (BTSC)
5 76.12% 78.57%
10 97.78% 99.11%
15 98.30% 99.26%
20 99.26% 99.55%
25 99.33% 99.63%
references: Finally, although the accuracy results are already high for flooding attacks, FL-IDS has been further improved with the BTSC method, as indicated in Table X.

S5.T11.caption: TABLE XI: Best/Worst Performance of Local IDSs in Detecting in Sinkhole Attacks
S5.T11.table:
Attacker Ratio (%) L-IDS FL-IDS L-IDS FL-IDS
Worst Best Worst Best Average Average
5 58.61% 98.33% 65.08% 80.63% 72.99% 70.68%
10 72.50% 98.96% 80.18% 95.23% 81.19% 88.12%
15 76.18% 99.51% 86.93% 97.74% 85.40% 93.53%
20 83.06% 99.93% 90.04% 98.92% 88.28% 96.43%
25 88.54% 99.93% 91.79% 99.41% 90.27% 97.36%
references: The results discussed above clearly show that when we centrally obtain local data and train a model using all these data, we can better differentiate attacks from benign network traffic. Therefore, Central IDS (C-IDS) demonstrates the best performance for each attack type. On the other hand, Federated IDS (FL-IDS) achieves competitive results with C-IDS. Particularly at higher attacker ratios, FL-IDS can approach the accuracy of C-IDS. Because, when the attacker ratio increases, more devices affected by such attacks can positively participate in training of FL-IDS. This is also supported by the improvement obtained with the use of BTSC, which selectively considers the best clients for training FL-IDS.

Local IDSs (L-IDS) have a lower success rate on average compared to other IDSs. The performance of L-IDS is calculated as the average of each local client. Therefore, L-IDS only show comparable results with C-IDS and FL-IDS in detecting flooding attacks due to the nature of this attack type, which affects most of the nodes in the network. However, when the impact of an attack is limited, as is the case with sinkhole and blackhole attacks that affect specific victims and its surroundings, the average accuracy of local IDSs might not be high. This discrepancy arises because while some clients can effectively detect attacks due to their location (such as being situated in active routes or denser areas), others may have less success.
The performance of individual local IDS has been compared in Tables
XI
XII
, and
XIII

for sinkhole, blackhole, and flooding attacks, respectively. These tables display the performance of the best and worst local IDS for both L-IDS and FL-IDS, as well as their average performance. One notable observation is that local ID systems, which receive feedback from the global model as part of federated learning, exhibit significantly superior performance compared to traditional L-IDS. FL-IDS effectively leverages the advantages of both centralized and local approaches, resulting in competitive accuracy levels across a variety of attacker ratios. However, it is worth noting that L-IDS outperforms FL-IDS at the lowest attacker ratios for blackhole and sinkhole attacks. In contrast, when dealing with flooding attacks and as the number of affected nodes in the network increases, FL-IDS shows better performance than L-IDS even at the lowest attacker ratio. Hence, it is recommended to employ BTSC for training IDS in the context of federated learning. This approach results in improved performance, particularly when a significant portion of the network’s clients remains unaffected by the attack.
Table
XIV

provides information about the Detection Rate (DR) and False Positive Rate (FPR) for each type of attack. The results reveal that all IDS models exhibit relatively high false positive rates at the lowest attacker ratio. However, as the attacker ratio increases, the FPR tends to decrease to reasonable levels. Notably, when the network contains a significant number of attackers (around 20% to 25%), each IDS models’ performance approaches an ideal scenario. In flooding attacks, IDS converge toward the ideal scenario even when the attacker ratio is as low as 10% in the network, since this attack causes significant harm to the network. Unlike other attacks, flooding attacks affect nearly all nodes, making it easier to differentiate abnormal data from normal data. It is worth highlighting that, on average, blackhole attacks perform slightly better than sinkhole attacks. While these attacks share similarities in directing traffic through attacker nodes, blackhole attacks also drop the packets they attract. This action might lead to an interruption in network traffic, as legitimate packets fail to reach their intended destinations. This disruption in network communications is more readily detectable because it directly impacts connectivity and traffic flow.

To summarize, FL-IDS demonstrates high performance in detecting a range of network attacks, including blackhole, sinkhole, and flooding attacks. Notably, when it is trained with the BTSC, FL-IDS even approaches the performance level of traditional Centralized IDS (C-IDS). This is achieved without the need for centrally collecting all local data, showcasing the remarkable effectiveness of federated learning in network security. Through FL-IDS, local clients can learn and adapt independently while benefiting from global model updates. In addition to improving overall performance, this collaboration helps in addressing complex and evolving threats that individual clients might not have encountered. With periodic retraining and ongoing evolution of the global model, FL-IDS ensures that it stays current and effective in countering both existing and emerging threats, while seamlessly welcoming new nodes into the network.

references: Table XIV provides information about the Detection Rate (DR) and False Positive Rate (FPR) for each type of attack. The results reveal that all IDS models exhibit relatively high false positive rates at the lowest attacker ratio. However, as the attacker ratio increases, the FPR tends to decrease to reasonable levels. Notably, when the network contains a significant number of attackers (around 20% to 25%), each IDS models’ performance approaches an ideal scenario. In flooding attacks, IDS converge toward the ideal scenario even when the attacker ratio is as low as 10% in the network, since this attack causes significant harm to the network. Unlike other attacks, flooding attacks affect nearly all nodes, making it easier to differentiate abnormal data from normal data. It is worth highlighting that, on average, blackhole attacks perform slightly better than sinkhole attacks. While these attacks share similarities in directing traffic through attacker nodes, blackhole attacks also drop the packets they attract. This action might lead to an interruption in network traffic, as legitimate packets fail to reach their intended destinations. This disruption in network communications is more readily detectable because it directly impacts connectivity and traffic flow.
